name: Solomon Islands Skink
description: It has a large head, short legs, and tough, glossy scales. It’s green dorsally, sometimes with dark spots, and yellowish ventrally. The tail is prehensile.
food_note: Tree leaves and other plant food
image_alt: Solomon Islands Skink, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Length 45–75 cm, with the tail comprising about 55%; weight 0.5 kg
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 6–8 months, giving birth to 1, rarely 2, young.
attractions: The Solomon Islands skink differs from other skinks by living in groups. Both parents and other group members care for the young, even adopting abandoned juveniles found in their territory. They use their tails to climb in tree canopies. In danger, they can shed their tail, which regrows later. They’re crepuscular.
breeding: We’ve kept these skinks continuously since 1989.
